io.amelia.plugins

Class PluginMeta

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.util.AbstractMap<K,V>
      • java.util.HashMap<java.lang.String,java.lang.Object>
        • io.amelia.foundation.MetaMap
          • io.amelia.foundation.VendorMeta
            • io.amelia.plugins.PluginMeta
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Cloneable, java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.Object>

    public class PluginMeta
extends VendorMeta
    This type is the runtime-container for the information in the plugin.yaml. All plugins must have a respective plugin.yaml. For plugins written in java using the standard plugin loader, this file must be in the root of the jar file.

    When the server loads a plugin, it needs to know some basic information about it. It reads this information from a YAML file, 'plugin.yaml'. This file consists of a set of attributes, each defined on a new line and with no indentation.

    Every (almost* every) method corresponds with a specific entry in the plugin.yaml. These are the required entries for every plugin.yaml:

    • VendorMeta.getName() - name
    • VendorMeta.getVersion() - version
    • getMain() - main

    Failing to include any of these items will throw an exception and cause the server to ignore your plugin.

    This is a list of the possible yaml keys, with specific details included in the respective method documentations: Node Method Summary name VendorMeta.getName() The unique name of plugin version VendorMeta.getVersion() A plugin revision identifier main getMain() The plugin's initial class file author
    authors VendorMeta.getAuthors() The plugin contributors description VendorMeta.getDescription() Human readable plugin summary website VendorMeta.getWebsite() The URL to the plugin's site prefix VendorMeta.getLoggerPrefix() The token to prefix plugin log entries load getLoad() The phase of server-startup this plugin will load during depend getDepend() Other required plugins libraries getLibraries() Required java libraries softdepend getSoftDepend() Other plugins that add functionality loadbefore getLoadBefore() The inverse softdepend

    A plugin.yaml example:

     name: SuperAwesomePlugin
 version: 1.0.4
 description: This plugin does something really awesome to the server
 author: SomeAuthor
 authors: [SomeAuthor, God, Jesus]
 website: http://www.superawesomeplugin.com

 main: com.superawesomeplugin.plugin.Main
 depend: [EmailPlugin]

 commands:
   doit:
     description: Does that super awesome thing
     aliases: [doit2, ihateyou]
     permission: io.amelia.destruction
     usage: Type /<doit> to do that super awesome thing.

    XXX Rewrite the description file read process to make it easier to implement

    See Also:

    • Method Detail

      • getDepend

        public java.util.List<java.lang.String> getDepend()
        Gives a list of other plugins that the plugin requires.
        • Use the value in the VendorMeta.getName() of the target plugin to specify the dependency.
        • If any plugin listed here is not found, your plugin will fail to load at startup.
        • If multiple plugins list each other in depend, creating a network with no individual plugin does not list another plugin in the network, all plugins in that network will fail.
        • depend must be in must be in YAML list format.

        In the plugin.yaml, this entry is named depend.

        Example: 

         depend:
 - OnePlugin
 - AnotherPlugin

        Returns:
        immutable list of the plugin's dependencies

      • getLibraries

        public java.util.List<MavenReference> getLibraries()
        Gives a list of java libraries required by this plugin.
        • Use the maven group:name:version string to specify the library.
        • If any libraries listed here are not found or can't be parsed, your plugin will fail to load at startup.
        • libraries must be in YAML list format.
        • For the time being, libraries are downloaded from the Central Maven Repository. We have plans to implement the ability to specify repositories, maybe even upload your libraries and plugins to our own central download server.

        In the plugin.yaml, this entry is named libraries.

        Example: 

         libraries:
 - com.dropbox.core:dropbox-core-sdk:1.7.7
 - org.apache.commons:commons-lang3:3.3.2

        Returns:
        immutable list of the plugin's dependencies

      • getLoad

        public Runlevel getLoad()
        Gives the phase of server startup that the plugin should be loaded.
        • Possible values are in Runlevel.
        • Defaults to Runlevel.STARTUP.
        • Certain caveats apply to each phase.
        • When different, getDepend(), getSoftDepend(), and getLoadBefore() become relative in order loaded per-phase. If a plugin loads at STARTUP, but a dependency loads at RUNNING, the dependency will not be loaded before the plugin is loaded.

        In the plugin.yaml, this entry is named runlevel.

        Example:

         load: STARTUP

        Returns:
        the phase when the plugin should be loaded

      • getLoadBefore

        public java.util.List<java.lang.String> getLoadBefore()
        Gets the list of plugins that should consider this plugin a soft-dependency.
        • Use the value in the VendorMeta.getName() of the target plugin to specify the dependency.
        • The plugin should load before any other plugins listed here.
        • Specifying another plugin here is strictly equivalent to having the specified plugin's getSoftDepend() include this plugin.
        • loadbefore must be in YAML list format.

        In the plugin.yaml, this entry is named loadbefore.

        Example: 

         loadbefore:
 - OnePlugin
 - AnotherPlugin

        Returns:
        immutable list of plugins that should consider this plugin a soft-dependency

      • getMain

        public java.lang.String getMain()

      • getMainRequired

        public java.lang.String getMainRequired()
                                 throws PluginMetaException
        Gives the fully qualified name of the main class for a plugin. The format should follow the ClassLoader.loadClass(String) syntax to successfully be resolved at runtime. For most plugins, this is the class that extends
        • This must contain the full namespace including the class file itself.
        • If your namespace is com.chiorichan.plugin, and your class file is called MyPlugin then this must be com.chiorichan.plugin.MyPlugin
        • No plugin can use org.bukkit. as a base package for any class, including the main class.

        In the plugin.yaml, this entry is named main.

        Example: 

         main: org.bukkit.plugin.MyPlugin

        Returns:
        the fully qualified main class for the plugin
        Throws:
        PluginMetaException

      • getNameWithException

        public java.lang.String getNameWithException()
                                      throws PluginMetaException
        Gives the name of the plugin. This name is a unique identifier for plugins.
        • Must consist of all alphanumeric characters, underscores, hyphon, and period (a-z,A-Z,0-9, _.-). Any other character will cause the plugin.yaml to fail loading.
        • Used to determine the name of the plugin's data folder. Data folders are placed in the ./plugins/ directory by default, but this behavior should not be relied on.
        • It is good practice to name your jar the same as this, for example 'MyPlugin.jar'.
        • Case sensitive.
        • The is the token referenced in getDepend(), getSoftDepend(), and getLoadBefore().

        In the plugin.yaml, this entry is named name.

        Example:

         name: MyPlugin

        Returns:
        the name of the plugin
        Throws:
        PluginMetaException

      • getNatives

        public java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.util.List<java.lang.String>> getNatives()

      • getSoftDepend

        public java.util.List<java.lang.String> getSoftDepend()
        Gives a list of other plugins that the plugin requires for full functionality. The DefaultPlugins will make best effort to treat all entries here as if they were a dependency, but will never fail because of one of these entries.
        • Use the value in the VendorMeta.getName() of the target plugin to specify the dependency.
        • When an unresolvable plugin is listed, it will be ignored and does not affect load order.
        • When a circular dependency occurs (a network of plugins depending or soft-dependending each other), it will arbitrarily choose a plugin that can be resolved when ignoring soft-dependencies.
        • softdepend must be in YAML list format.

        In the plugin.yaml, this entry is named softdepend.

        Example: 

         softdepend: [OnePlugin, AnotherPlugin]

        Returns:
        immutable list of the plugin's preferred dependencies
